7.22.24  4:21 pm   how to make the everything smaller and more manageable?

      what i want to suggest is to start making a list of as many different ways as you can think of. and this may excite you. that's what works for me, but on the other hand i think some people are excited in totally different ways than i am, so i really don't know

7.22.24  3:51 pm   what time is it?

      dinsdag 23 juli 2024 03:11:22

7.22.24  3:37 pm   Hey, my question basically could be summarized as "how did you develop yourself as a musician?" (out of curiosity), and also, maybe, "how do you 'understand/(feel about)' music?", but unsure about that last one. Also, sorry if I ask too much and feel free to omit [not answer everything]. Relatively recently, I got more curious than I've ever been about music. And I found on the internet that you're self-taught and (from what I understand) that you don't really like music theory, and say that music can't really be described like that [sorry if I oversimplfy or misunderstand some stuff]. Which sounds kinda like the approach I would want to take to understand music better and/or maybe even write some of my own music later on. I think what sparkled my curiosity in music, was that some particular songs made me feel specific feelings, some songs being especially intense in that (a large amount of feeling ignited) [How did you get into music? (curiosity)].

     music is an irresistibly strong magical power. it's a no brainer for me to develop that to the best of my ability. the first time i got hooked on it was certainly too early in my life to recall. it was before i learned to speak

      So, that made me curious why those songs in particular and how do they make me feel such intense feelings [Do you have songs that made you experience similar things? Do you have the means (what sort of means? how did you get those means?) to explain that, or did you just accept the feelings without questioning them? (Other?)].

     you can spend many lifetimes trying to explain exactly how this stuff works. i've certainly given it an earnest try from time to time. and as far as i know, no one really knows. although i'm sure someone will try to tell you they know

     It seems to me that the two most important things in a song to me are "feeling" and "story". "Story" isn't necessarily lyrics; it could be fully instrumental song, it just may feel like the melody is still telling a story. And "feeling" is 'simply' the fact that melody evokes particular feelings. So, if I were to compose music, I feel like I would want to have these 2 [Do you have "similar" ideas about music, that you possibly apply to composing your own pieces of music?]

     from all the years of trying to 'understand' 'why' this stuff works, or what's really going on, a few basic principles tend to keep emerging. one theme is "making patterns, and then breaking them", which of course can be applied recursively as the make-break becomes its own pattern which in turn can be broken. And another strong theme that comes up is the idea that you have to prove you're really there

     The problem is that I know like nothing about music, and when I'm behind the keyboard I basically can do only hit random keys,

     right but as soon as the sound comes out you realize it's not random at all

     and actually they sometimes provide some melodies(, etc) that sound somewhat adequate, and I actually made one into somewhat of a song. So, while this random hitting could provide some ideas, and maybe it is the way to discover music vocabulary, I am completely clueless as to how to transfer the feeling and the story with some sort of intent. And maybe my story/feeling idea isn't even the right approach to making music after all.

     i think with enough time and experience it's gonna work fine. like learning a language, it may take years, but inevitably you will get there if you just find a way to keep enjoying it and being curious

     [How did you start to compose music, and how did that change over time?]

     at a certain point you start to notice that you come up with ideas when you're not trying to, or when you're not supposed to. and then when you really try to, you clam up. gradually you start to learn how to strategically get that all sorted out, but it's taken me years upon years upon years upon years. maybe the first time i really wrote anything was like 6 or 7 years after i was first introduced to music, but then it was many many many many years later before i had anything with words in it, and then a few more heaps of years more before i did anything you've ever heard from me, surely

     And finally, while I am at it (at asking bajilion questions): 1. How did you learn to sing while being self-taught? I would be curious to learn how to sing (at least a bit, for the sake of understanding music), but this one feels by far the scariest, as to not pick up bad habits, improper techniques, and not injure throat.

     just doing it a lot, it usually gets better the more you do it. at some point i heard some hints about how to not hurt yourself, but most of the technical desctiptions of how to breathe and use this and that muscle and whatever, didn't make any sense to me. i've had far more success thinking of it in terms of acting. thinking of it as a form of communication

     2. How did you develop your "ear"? In particular, how was the "the high class stuff" video made? The transcription of pitches of the speaking voice and the insane rhythms in it (weird rests ("offbeat"?), weird durations, triplets, quintuplets).

     i'm not sure, but it occurs to me to ask you how you think you learned how to write and spell so well, in english. whatever mechanism that is, it's pretty much the same thing. and it also takes a lot of time probably

     This text is so large so that I have to thank you just for reading it, and also thanks for answering on top of that.

7.22.24  3:30 pm   is english a better lingua franca than other existing languages? is it just by happenstance that it became a lingua franca? in my mind, it seems like any language could work since, for example, i've met native greek- and turkish-speakers in germany speaking german. but also i  could see an argument that english is such an amalgamation of other languages that it sounds equally foreign wherever it's spoken.

      qualitatively there's nothing special about english. but lingua francas aren't usually determined by their qualities. it's just whatever language is already most widely spoken, and then it snowballs because more people want to learn it because more people speak it. the reason it originally became so widely spoken might have something to do with britain and then later usa going around the world and introducing themselves so emphatically

7.22.24  12:04 pm   Hello!! Ive been a big fan of your work for a while but I actually have a couple questions. First: Is there any possibility i could work with you?

     it's possible

     I have an electric piano with 482 different instruments (counting sound effects) and i feel like i could help with music and all that.

     in that sense i don't think it would make sense for you to work with me, but perhaps in other ways

      second: where do you get your video ideas from?

     ideas technically come from absolutely everywhere

      third: is this message too long?

     not quite

     and finally: what is the password to reality on your website?

     there is no password. the password box has no functionality

      you don't have to say it, you can just give me a clue or two. Anyways, that just about wraps it up, keep up the good work on your music and videos.

7.21.24  3:39 am   These days I tend to get maybe about 1.5 minutes into writing a song no problem before hitting walls, because at that point writing further can become time consuming and maybe even tedious, since usually you have to do full run throughs and hope the ether gives you what happens next. I will say I hit that wall in writing today and tried that idea of making it bad on purpose, and it literally completely worked and propelled the whole thing forward into the right direction. I think the idea works because fundamentally good songs play, like play around, and trying something bad to throw a wrench in the whole thing is sometimes the right chaos and the order / clean up that follows feels so good. Kinda weird. Would you agree with that, or do you think it's silly to try to figure out the secret sauce behind the secret sauce of trying something bad on purpose

      in this case, there is somewhat of a tendency for me to think that you've just deliberately paraphrased my own views back to me

7.21.24  3:30 am   Will I find my reason in living?

      i think so

7.20.24  8:08 pm   how would you go about enduring the 15-or-so seconds when you're sealed in at the top of a drop waterslide, and you literally can't breathe or think of anything except for "i'm going to die i'm going to die holy shit-"?

      that depends on whether the rest of the experience is so good that it outweighs that trauma. if it's not, then the way i'd deal with this is by skipping the whole thing, and not doing it. but if it's worth it, then the way i would deal with that is to do it more often. but unfortunately that also might weaken the effectiveness of the overall experience
